odrl:policy.dcterms:title: Protected A Data — LLM Usage Policy
Protected B Data — LLM Usage Policy

@graph.dcterms:title: Knowledge graph construction from authoritative sources
Considerations for the use of Generative AI (ITSAP.00.041)
Guide on the Use of Generative AI
Departmental Responsibilities for Automated Decision Systems
The Directive on Automated Decision-Making compliance deadline is June 24, 2026
The AIA has four impact levels: Level I (little/no impact), Level II (moderate), Level III (high), Level IV (very high)
AIA Level III and IV systems require human-in-the-loop for all decisions
AIA Level II and above systems require peer review by a qualified expert
Sending Protected B personal information to commercial LLM vendors constitutes unlawful disclosure under Privacy Act s.8
All public-facing LLM outputs must be available simultaneously in English and French at equal quality
Bill C-27 / AIDA (Artificial Intelligence and Data Act) was not enacted and is not law
The GC AI Register tracks over 400 automated decision systems across 42 federal institutions

CCCS identifies 8 generative AI threat categories: prompt injection, data poisoning, training data extraction, model manipulation, supply chain, denial of service, output manipulation, and privilege escalation
FASTER principles: Fair, Accountable, Secure, Transparent, Educated, Relevant
GC data classification levels for LLM usage: Unclassified (commercial LLMs permitted), Protected A (GC-controlled infrastructure), Protected B (GC cloud with PII blocking)
Departments must publish an algorithmic impact assessment before deploying any automated decision system
LLM response generation (constrained by knowledge graph)
@graph.dcterms:description: Each LLM response traces to specific facts from the knowledge graph, which in turn trace to authoritative source documents

skos:hasTopConcept.skos:definition: Root governance framework definition
Federal legislation creating binding obligations
Treasury Board directive or mandatory policy instrument
Non-binding guidance document from TBS or CCCS
CCCS security guidance for generative AI threats
Named principle framework (e.g., FASTER)
AIA algorithmic impact assessment level (I-IV)
Measurable control derived from an obligation
Enforceable rule that can be tested at compile time
ODRL policy constraint per data classification level
Cloud or self-hosted LLM service provider
Reference LLM deployment with constraint binding
Knowledge boundary defining permitted/excluded topics
Verified fact from an authoritative source
Trusted source document with integrity metadata
Authoritative definition preventing LLM-invented terms
Runtime data classification checkpoint
Runtime EN/FR quality validation checkpoint
Human review checkpoint for high-impact decisions
PROV-O audit trail collecting LLM response provenance
EARL smoke test validating runtime control
SHACL ValidationReport for auditors
VC 2.0 credential attesting compliance
DCAT 3 catalog entry for GC AI Register
OWL-Time schedule for compliance deadlines
